bibl.title: Letter from L.O. Howard to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 1, 1924

div1.p: Howard responds favorably to Kean's letter published in the New York Times, and offers supporting evidence for Kean's claims in the form of quotations from a letter of Reed.

div1.head: Letter from L.O. Howard to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 1, 1924
div1.opener:
FROM L. O. HOWARD
OR LUCY HOWARD
May 1, 1924.
Col. J. R. Kean, M. C., U. S. Army,
c/o War Department,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Colonel Kean:
div1.p:
Dr. L. H. Baekeland, who has been here attending the
meetings of the National Academy of Sciences for the last three days,
called my attention to your letter in the Sunday New York Times,
which I had unfortunately missed. I at once secured a copy of the
article, and wish to thank you and congratulate you. I know very
well the facts which you recite, and I remember that you were adminis-
trating mosquito extermination in those late days of 1900. It
might interest you to know, in regard to the statement that Reed's
demonstration was a more academic performance which Reed himself saw
no practical way of applying," that Reed wrote me a bully letter from
Los Animas in which he showed that he fully knew the practical outcome
of his discovery; and of course every one who talked with him at that
period knows that the practical end was filling his mind. Reed's letter
was written January 13, 1901. I may quote from the middle of the
letter--

“The mosquito theory for the propagation of yellow fever
is no longer a theory but a well established fact. Isn't it enough
to make a fellow feel happy? Anopheles and Culex are a gay old pair:
What havoc they have wrought on our species during the last three
centuries! But with ‘Howard and kerosene’ we are going to knock
them out.”
To this letter Reed added the following postscript:

“Major J. R. Kean, Surgeon, U.S.A., was the Acting Chief
Surgeon of the Division of Cuba at the time this order was published,
and it was he who drew it up and recommended it to General Wood. He
should have credit for it.”

So you see Reed himself not only appreciated the practical
part to the fullest degree, but he gave both you and myself full credit.

FROM L. O. HOWARD
OR LUCY HOWARD
I wish I might see you some day and talk these things over.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Chief of Bureau. loh-wft
